--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <tucker0171@y...> wrote:
> > It's pretty clear from this discussion that the way Derek and
Philip
> > are activating their networks is not the standard way it works in
> > NEAT, because in standard NEAT, you don't need to keep activation
in
> > memory from the previous timestep.  
> 
> From the FAQ:
> "Each node adds up the activation from all incoming nodes from the 
> previous timestep."
> 
> How do you add the activation from the previous time step if that 
> activation is not in memory?
> 

I can see I totally mispoke.  There *is* a memory at every node.  What
I meant to convey is that there is not a *special* memory just for
recurrent connections.

I'll try to respond to the rest later..but I just wanted to quickly
clear up any confusion I caused.  It sounds like you were
understanding things correctly from the FAQ.

ken
